title: Essex lorry deaths: Vietnamese group receives photos of around 20 missing people from worried families
text:
A Vietnamese group in the UK has received around 20 photos of people reported missing since 39 people were found dead in a lorry in Essex.

The website Viethome said it wanted to “focus on filtering information, finding missing people and confirming the victims' identities”, and that it was engaging with UK police on the matter.

One of those reported missing is aged just 15, while the eldest is 45, the group said.

Viethome said it had believed that those who were on the “death bus” would have entered the vehicle between 3pm on Monday and 1pm on Tuesday, so it was trying to narrow down potential victims based on this time frame.

Three people have been arrested on suspicion of manslaughter and people trafficking after 39 bodies were discovered in a refrigerated lorry trailer in Grays, Essex.

A 48-year-old man from Northern Ireland was arrested at Stansted Airport on Friday, police said, after a couple were detained in Warrington in Cheshire overnight on Thursday.

It emerged on Friday that a missing Vietnamese woman had texted her mother to say “I can’t breathe” at the time the lorry was being shipped from Belgium to the UK on Tuesday night.

Pham Thi Tra My, 26, sent a message saying “I’m dying”, and has not been heard from since.

The text was sent at 4.28am on Wednesday Vietnamese time, the screenshot shows. In Britain the time would have been 10.28pm, when the trailer was in transit between Zebrugge and Purrfleet.

The bodies were found on an industrial estate in Grays just over three hours later.

Another Vietnamese citizen feared to have been in a truck is Nguyen Dinh Luong, 20, whose father said he received a chilling call to say his son died en route to the UK.

Nguyen Dinh Gia said his son told him two weeks ago he planned to travel to Britain from France, where he had been living illegally since 2018, and that he would pay 11,000 pounds ($14,000) for the journey.

But Mr Gia got a call several days ago from a Vietnamese man saying “Please have some sympathy, something unexpected happened,” he told AFP.

“I fell to the ground when I heard that,” he said. “It seemed that he was in the truck with the accident, all of them dead."

Detectives had initially believed all 31 men and eight women found in the trailer were Chinese, but on Friday night they said the nationality of those killed was “now a developing picture”.
